channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Overlooked Drug Could Save Thousands Of Moms After Childbirth
item.description: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/26/525639110/overlooked-drug-could-save-thousands-of-moms-after-childbirth

item.title: Swipe Right To Help Save The Northern White Rhino From Extinction
item.description: April 26, 2017 - To fund in vitro fertilization research, Ol Pejeta Conservancy CEO Richard Vigne says researchers teamed up with the dating app Tinder to feature "Sudan" as the "Most Eligible Bachelor in the World."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - To fund in vitro fertilization research, Ol Pejeta Conservancy CEO Richard Vigne says researchers teamed up with the dating app Tinder to feature "Sudan" as the "Most Eligible Bachelor in the World." http://www.npr.org/2017/04/26/525764720/swipe-right-to-help-save-the-northern-white-rhino-from-extinction

item.title: 'Minibrains' In A Dish Shed A Little Light On Autism And Epilepsy
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/26/525705550/minibrains-in-a-dish-shed-a-little-light-on-autism-and-epilepsy

item.title: New Evidence Suggests Humans Arrived In The Americas Far Earlier Than Thought
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Until now, the earliest signs of humans in the Americas dated back about 15,000 years. But new research puts people in California 130,000 years ago. Experts are wondering whether to believe it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Until now, the earliest signs of humans in the Americas dated back about 15,000 years. But new research puts people in California 130,000 years ago. Experts are wondering whether to believe it. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/26/525628056/new-evidence-suggests-humans-arrived-in-the-americas-far-earlier-than-thought

item.title: Cassini Spacecraft Starts Weaving Between Saturn And Its Rings
item.description: April 26, 2017 - "Shields Up!" the Cassini craft's Twitter feed announced Wednesday. If all goes well, new images of the ringed planet will reach Earth early Thursday.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - "Shields Up!" the Cassini craft's Twitter feed announced Wednesday. If all goes well, new images of the ringed planet will reach Earth early Thursday. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/26/525696238/cassini-spacecraft-starts-weaving-between-saturn-and-its-rings

item.title: Energy Star Program For Homes And Appliances Is On Trump's Chopping Block
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Appliance makers and home builders are in Washington, D.C., to celebrate the energy efficiency program. Energy Star is among 50 EPA programs that would be eliminated under the president's budget plan.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Appliance makers and home builders are in Washington, D.C., to celebrate the energy efficiency program. Energy Star is among 50 EPA programs that would be eliminated under the president's budget plan. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/26/525584142/energy-star-program-for-homes-and-appliances-is-on-trumps-chopping-block

item.title: How A Wild Berry Is Helping To Protect China's Giant Pandas And Its Countryside
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/26/525552957/how-a-wild-berry-helped-save-china-s-giant-pandas-and-its-countryside

item.title: Recordings Reveal That Baby Humpback Whales 'Whisper' To Their Mothers
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Scientists recently tracked eight baby whales using special sound and movement recorders. The sounds the babies made turned out to be far different from the eerie songs of adult male humpbacks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Scientists recently tracked eight baby whales using special sound and movement recorders. The sounds the babies made turned out to be far different from the eerie songs of adult male humpbacks. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/26/525609671/recordings-reveal-baby-humpback-whales-whisper-to-their-mothers

item.title: The Lowly Wax Worm May Hold The Key To Biodegrading Plastic
item.description: April 25, 2017 - More than a trillion plastic bags are used annually. They're made of a notoriously resilient kind of plastic called polyethylene – but scientists have found that wax worms are able to break them down.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - More than a trillion plastic bags are used annually. They're made of a notoriously resilient kind of plastic called polyethylene – but scientists have found that wax worms are able to break them down. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/25/525447206/a-worm-may-hold-the-key-to-biodegrading-plastic

item.title: Flying Cars Are (Still) Coming: Should We Believe The Hype?
item.description: April 25, 2017 - Airbus and Uber are planning for a future of flying cars and sky taxis. "You literally push a button and you get a flight," an Uber executive says. But will our Tomorrowland ever really arrive?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - Airbus and Uber are planning for a future of flying cars and sky taxis. "You literally push a button and you get a flight," an Uber executive says. But will our Tomorrowland ever really arrive? http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/04/25/525540611/flying-cars-are-still-coming-should-we-believe-the-hype

item.title: Psychiatrist Recalls 'Heartbreak And Hope' On Bellevue's Prison Ward
item.description: April 25, 2017 - Dr. Elizabeth Ford treated mentally ill inmates in New York City for more than a decade. It was almost universal, she says, that they had suffered abuse or significant neglect as children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - Dr. Elizabeth Ford treated mentally ill inmates in New York City for more than a decade. It was almost universal, she says, that they had suffered abuse or significant neglect as children. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/25/525533732/psychiatrist-recalls-heartbreak-and-hope-on-bellevues-prison-ward

item.title: Changes To Federal Insurance Plans Could Hurt Families Of Chronically Ill Kids
item.description: April 25, 2017 - Some urge ending funding to the Children's Health Insurance Program, and moving those 8 million kids to marketplace plans. But research shows the out-of-pocket costs to many families would soar.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - Some urge ending funding to the Children's Health Insurance Program, and moving those 8 million kids to marketplace plans. But research shows the out-of-pocket costs to many families would soar. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/25/525475221/changes-to-federal-insurance-plans-could-hurt-families-of-chronically-ill-kids

item.title: Eat, Sleep, Repeat: How Kids' Daily Routines Can Help Prevent Obesity
item.description: April 25, 2017 - A new study finds that preschool-age children who didn't have a set sleep routine were more likely to be overweight by the time they hit the preteen years.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 25, 2017 - A new study finds that preschool-age children who didn't have a set sleep routine were more likely to be overweight by the time they hit the preteen years. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/25/525394739/eat-sleep-repeat-how-kids-daily-routines-can-help-prevent-obesity

item.title: What Fish Is Good For Me And The Planet? New Documentary Explores
item.description: April 24, 2017 - In order to investigate how eating fish affects our health as well as the oceans, author and fisherman Paul Greenberg spent a year eating fish every day.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 24, 2017 - In order to investigate how eating fish affects our health as well as the oceans, author and fisherman Paul Greenberg spent a year eating fish every day. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/24/525111293/what-fish-is-good-for-me-and-the-planet-new-documentary-explores

item.title: Hacking Lake Erie: Tech Competition Seeks Solutions To Water-Related Problems
item.description: April 24, 2017 - A technology competition seeks solutions to Lake Erie's biggest problems, including harmful algae blooms and aging water systems. Teams in cities around the region are competing for thousands of dollars in prize money and consulting services to create apps and other tools.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 24, 2017 - A technology competition seeks solutions to Lake Erie's biggest problems, including harmful algae blooms and aging water systems. Teams in cities around the region are competing for thousands of dollars in prize money and consulting services to create apps and other tools. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/24/525441604/hacking-lake-erie-tech-competition-seeks-solutions-to-water-related-problems
